titleStmt.title: The bishop busied beside the business, or, That eminent overseer, Dr. John Gauden, Bishop of Exeter, so eminently overseen as to wound his own cause well nigh to death with his own weapon in his late so super-eminently-applauded appearance for the [brace] liberty of tender consciences, legitimacy of solemn swearings, entituled, A discourse concerning publick oaths, and the lawfulness of swearing in judicial proceedings, in order to answer the scruples of the Quakers ... / by Samuel Fisher ...
titleStmt.author: Fisher, Samuel, 1605-1665.

titleStmt.title: The bishop busied beside the business, or, That eminent overseer, Dr. John Gauden, Bishop of Exeter, so eminently overseen as to wound his own cause well nigh to death with his own weapon in his late so super-eminently-applauded appearance for the [brace] liberty of tender consciences, legitimacy of solemn swearings, entituled, A discourse concerning publick oaths, and the lawfulness of swearing in judicial proceedings, in order to answer the scruples of the Quakers ... / by Samuel Fisher ...
titleStmt.author: Fisher, Samuel, 1605-1665.

notesStmt.note: At head of title: Epischopos aposchopos [Greek transliterated].
Place of publication suggested by Wing.
Error in paging: p. 43 of 2nd pt. misnumbered 45.
Imperfect: print show-through with considerable loss of print.
Reproduction of original in the Huntington Library.
